pullRequest.body:
Proof of several versions of Abel summation formula. 

This PR is part of the proof of the Analytic Class Number Formula.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e7997d9598](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19289/commits/e7997d9598b43c3e3624fe091a3d1d1ff30454e5)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.AbelSummation` (new file)|1987|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IntervalIntegrable.congr`
`+ _root_.sum_mul_eq_sub_sub_integral_mul`
`+ sum_Ioc_by_parts`
`+ sum_mul_eq_sub_integral_mul`
`+ sum_mul_eq_sub_integral_mul'`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Some comments on your proof.
- It's not much fun for authors, reviewers, or future editors to work on proofs of > 100 lines, because the tiniest edit causes the whole proof to recompile. Is there a way to extract some steps as separate lemmas (maybe flagged `private`)?
- You convert between ordered and un-ordered intervals **25 times** in this proof: 19 uses of `uIcc_of_le` and 6 more for the `Ioc` version. Are you sure there isn't a way of avoiding some of these conversions? As far as I can tell, for every `uIoc x y` or `uIcc x y` which appears in your argument, we always know straight away that `x ≤ y`; so why work with unordered intervals at all?
- `linarith` is an amazing tactic, but it can't see through the definition of intervals (ordered or unordered). Perhaps you could formulate `h_integ` and `h_locint` slightly differently, replacing the interval inclusions with explicitly-written inequalities, so that the proofs of the hypotheses could literally be `by linarith`?
Thanks for the comments. I'm going to be quite busy in the next few days but I'll find some time to improve the proof soon.

@loefflerd, I have modified the proof. Hopefully, it is better now. 

> * It's not much fun for authors, reviewers, or future editors to work on proofs of > 100 lines, because the tiniest edit causes the whole proof to recompile. Is there a way to extract some steps as separate lemmas (maybe flagged `private`)?

I have extracted several private lemmas from the main proof. I hope it makes things easier to work with. The proof is still quite technical, I am afraid,

> * You convert between ordered and un-ordered intervals **25 times** in this proof: 19 uses of `uIcc_of_le` and 6 more for the `Ioc` version. Are you sure there isn't a way of avoiding some of these conversions? As far as I can tell, for every `uIoc x y` or `uIcc x y` which appears in your argument, we always know straight away that `x ≤ y`; so why work with unordered intervals at all?

I tried to reduce the used of unordered intervals as much as possible. Still, at some point, there is the need to work with those because of the way [intervalIntegral](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Integral/IntervalIntegral.html#intervalIntegral) is defined. 

> * `linarith` is an amazing tactic, but it can't see through the definition of intervals (ordered or unordered). Perhaps you could formulate `h_integ` and `h_locint` slightly differently, replacing the interval inclusions with explicitly-written inequalities, so that the proofs of the hypotheses could literally be `by linarith`?

I replaced interval membership hypotheses  with explicit inequalities so that more things can be proved directly using `linarith`. I also tried to reduce the number of inequalities needed.

I think the code looks good now. One last tiny thing: the comment "we prove some inequalities to be used by linarith" is no longer accurate – can you update it? Sorry, I missed this earlier.

maintainer delegate
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

> I think the code looks good now. One last tiny thing: the comment "we prove some inequalities to be used by linarith" is no longer accurate – can you update it? Sorry, I missed this earlier.

I removed the comments. Thanks again for the review!

Thanks!

bors merge
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks for revising this! I think it's a lot better now. Here are some comments – I didn't have time to look at the "main" proof, I hope I should have some time look at it tomorrow.

```suggestion
variable (n)
```
`hn` is redundant with `hmn` (`Nat.one_le_of_lt`)
Oh right, thanks

```suggestion
  simp_rw [← smul_eq_mul, sum_Ioc_by_parts (fun k ↦ f k) _ (by linarith) hb, range_eq_Ico,
    Nat.Ico_succ_right, smul_eq_mul]
```
It's probably worth checking how many of those `linarith`s can be trivially replaced

I don't know about that... At first, I started to provide an explicit proof for all of these but it made the code very cumbersome and it was very tedious. Then I realized that all of these statements were very similar and could be deduced easily for a some basic inequalities and that `linarith` was perfect for that. 

I think these calls to `linarith` are very fast and illustrate the fact that all these little technical proofs do not deserve to spend any effort on them
Comment
You've marked this as resolved, but I think Ruben was trying to point out that you have a docstring in your code consisting of the word "docstring" (which is still there).
Yes, sorry. I made some fixes on my local git but I forgot to push it last night.

```suggestion
    rw [Nat.succ_eq_add_one, zero_add, ← Nat.floor_one (α := ℝ),
      sum_mul_eq_sub_sub_integral_mul c zero_le_one hb hf_diff hf_int, Nat.floor_one, Nat.cast_one,
      Finset.Icc_eq_cons_Ioc zero_le_one, sum_cons, ← zero_add (1 : ℕ), Nat.Ioc_succ_singleton,
      zero_add, sum_singleton, hc, mul_zero, zero_add]
```

Note that these are only for a sum of complex numbers; I didn't manage to derive the real version. (Is differentiability actually hard when you throw in the coercion from Real to Complex or am I bad at searching the library?)

Maybe these results should be namespaced under `Complex` to leave room for the real ones when we add them

I would suggest treating the real and complex version simultaneously using `RCLike`. If you assume `{𝕜 : Type*} [RCLike 𝕜] {f : ℝ → 𝕜} (c : ℕ → 𝕜)` then Xavier's proof works without any change at all.

(Probably it would work with vector-valued functions too, but that would be more awkward to formulate. I managed to get the proof working for `f` valued in an `RCLike 𝕜` and `c` valued in a general normed `𝕜`-vector space, modulo one `sorry` since `IntervalIntegrable.smul_const` doesn't exist; but the asymmetry is annoying, why should it be `c` that is vector-valued and not `f`?)

> I would suggest treating the real and complex version simultaneously using `RCLike`. If you assume `{𝕜 : Type*} [RCLike 𝕜] {f : ℝ → 𝕜} (c : ℕ → 𝕜)` then Xavier's proof works without any change at all.

I am always so amazed by Lean when things work that smoothly 😄 

> (Probably it would work with vector-valued functions too, but that would be more awkward to formulate. I managed to get the proof working for f valued in an RCLike 𝕜 and c valued in a general normed 𝕜-vector space, modulo one sorry since IntervalIntegrable.smul_const doesn't exist; but the asymmetry is annoying, why should it be c that is vector-valued and not f?)

Do you think this kind of generalization would be interesting?

> Do you think this kind of generalization would be interesting?

I don't have a particular application in mind, no. It's only worth doing if it's essentially free (which I think is not true).
Well, it will be for a future refactor then

equivalent but cleaner:
```suggestion
simpa only [← Nat.Ico_succ_succ, Nat.succ_eq_add_one, Nat.sub_add_cancel (Nat.one_le_of_lt hmn),
    add_tsub_cancel_right] using sum_Ico_by_parts f g (Nat.succ_lt_succ hmn)
```

```suggestion
  filter_upwards [Ico_ae_eq_Icc] with t h ht
```
(the goal view has some metavars after this, but they resolve in the next line)

`using by` is toggling back+forth between term-mode and tactic-mode, why not just
```suggestion
    filter_upwards [sumlocc c n] with t h h'
    rw [h (h_inc₁ h')]
```

```suggestion
  · have := (Set.mem_Ico.mp hk).1
    exact le_of_lt <| (Nat.floor_lt' (by omega)).mp this
  · rw [← Nat.cast_add_one, ← Nat.le_floor_iff' (Nat.succ_ne_zero k)]
```
(faster)

```suggestion
    a ≤ k ∧ k + 1 ≤ b := 
  ineqofmemIco (by rwa [← Finset.coe_Ico])
```

```suggestion
    (hf_int : IntegrableOn (deriv f) (Set.Icc a b)) :
```

I'm personally not so keen on the repeated use of `any_goals`. Some of the goals you are passing to `linarith` are utterly trivial (one of them is `b ≤ b`, for example); I think these should be dealt with as they arise (using `le_rfl`).

Here's my suggested alternative for this proof. It's actually a tiny bit longer than yours, but it compiles more than twice as fast, and I hope it's a bit more obvious how the pieces fit together in a way that might make it more maintainable in future (i.e. more robust against changes elsewhere in the library):

```suggestion
private theorem integrablemulsum (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hb : ⌊a⌋₊ < ⌊b⌋₊)
  (hf_int : IntegrableOn (deriv f) (Set.Icc a b)) :
    IntegrableOn (fun t ↦ deriv f t * (∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊t⌋₊, c k)) (Set.Icc a b) := by
  have h_locint {t₁ t₂ : ℝ} {n : ℕ} (h : t₁ ≤ t₂) (h₁ : n ≤ t₁) (h₂ : t₂ ≤ n + 1)
      (h₃ : a ≤ t₁) (h₄ : t₂ ≤ b) :
      IntervalIntegrable (fun t ↦ deriv f t * (∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊t⌋₊, c k)) volume t₁ t₂ := by
    rw [intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le h]
    exact (IntegrableOn.mono_set (hf_int.mul_const _) (Set.Icc_subset_Icc h₃ h₄)).congr
      <| ae_restrict_of_ae_restrict_of_subset (Set.Icc_subset_Icc h₁ h₂)
        <| (ae_restrict_iff' measurableSet_Icc).mpr
          (by filter_upwards [sumlocc c n] with t h ht using by rw [h ht])
  -- We prove some inequalities to be used later on
  have aux1 : 0 ≤ b := (Nat.pos_of_floor_pos <| (Nat.zero_le _).trans_lt hb).le
  have aux2 : ⌊a⌋₊ + 1 ≤ b := by rwa [← Nat.cast_add_one, ← Nat.le_floor_iff aux1]
  have aux3 : a ≤ ⌊a⌋₊ + 1 := (Nat.lt_floor_add_one _).le
  have aux4 : a ≤ ⌊b⌋₊ := le_of_lt (by rwa [← Nat.floor_lt ha])
  -- now break up into 3 subintervals
  rw [← intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le (aux3.trans aux2)]
  have I1 : IntervalIntegrable _ volume a ↑(⌊a⌋₊ + 1) :=
    h_locint (mod_cast aux3) (Nat.floor_le ha) (mod_cast le_rfl) le_rfl (mod_cast aux2)
  have I2 : IntervalIntegrable _ volume ↑(⌊a⌋₊ + 1) ⌊b⌋₊ :=
    trans_iterate_Ico hb fun k hk ↦ h_locint (mod_cast k.le_succ)
      le_rfl (mod_cast le_rfl) (ineqofmemIco hk).1 (mod_cast (ineqofmemIco hk).2)
  have I3 : IntervalIntegrable _ volume ⌊b⌋₊ b :=
    h_locint (Nat.floor_le aux1) le_rfl (Nat.lt_floor_add_one _).le aux4 le_rfl
  exact (I1.trans I2).trans I3
```
Yes, I agree that your version is cleaner and today I learned about `mod_cast` which is really helpful here.

Here's a version which compiles 3.5x quicker, at the cost of slightly less automation:
```suggestion
/-- Abel's summation formula. -/
theorem _root_.sum_mul_eq_sub_sub_integral_mul (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hab : a ≤ b)
    (hf_diff : ∀ t ∈ Set.Icc a b, DifferentiableAt ℝ f t)
    (hf_int : IntegrableOn (deriv f) (Set.Icc a b)) :
    ∑ k ∈ Ioc ⌊a⌋₊ ⌊b⌋₊, f k * c k =
      f b * (∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊b⌋₊, c k) - f a * (∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊a⌋₊, c k) -
        ∫ t in a..b, deriv f t * (∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊t⌋₊, c k) := by
  -- We prove some inequalities to be used later on by linarith
  have aux1 : ⌊a⌋₊ ≤ a := Nat.floor_le ha
  have aux2 : b ≤ ⌊b⌋₊ + 1 := (Nat.lt_floor_add_one _).le
  -- We consider two cases depending on whether the sum is empty or not
  obtain hb | hb := eq_or_lt_of_le (Nat.floor_le_floor hab)
  · rw [hb, Ioc_eq_empty_of_le le_rfl, sum_empty, ← sub_mul,
      integralmulsum c hf_diff hf_int _ _ ⌊b⌋₊ hab (hb ▸ aux1) aux2 le_rfl le_rfl, sub_self]
  -- Some more inequalities for linarith
  have aux3 : a ≤ ⌊a⌋₊ + 1 := (Nat.lt_floor_add_one _).le
  have aux4 : ⌊a⌋₊ + 1 ≤ b := by rwa [← Nat.cast_add_one,  ← Nat.le_floor_iff (ha.trans hab)]
  have aux5 : ⌊b⌋₊ ≤ b := Nat.floor_le (ha.trans hab)
  have aux6 : a ≤ ⌊b⌋₊ := Nat.floor_lt ha |>.mp hb |>.le
  simp_rw [← smul_eq_mul, sum_Ioc_by_parts (fun k ↦ f k) _ hb, range_eq_Ico, Nat.Ico_succ_right,
    smul_eq_mul]
  have : ∑ k ∈ Ioc ⌊a⌋₊ (⌊b⌋₊ - 1), (f ↑(k + 1) - f k) * ∑ n ∈ Icc 0 k, c n =
        ∑ k ∈ Ico (⌊a⌋₊ + 1) ⌊b⌋₊, ∫ t in k..↑(k + 1), deriv f t * ∑ n ∈ Icc 0 ⌊t⌋₊, c n := by
    rw [← Nat.Ico_succ_succ, Nat.succ_eq_add_one,  Nat.succ_eq_add_one, Nat.sub_add_cancel
      (by omega), Eq.comm]
    exact sum_congr rfl fun k hk ↦ (integralmulsum c hf_diff hf_int _ _ _  (mod_cast k.le_succ)
      le_rfl (mod_cast le_rfl) (ineqofmemIco' hk).1 <| mod_cast (ineqofmemIco' hk).2)
  rw [this, sum_integral_adjacent_intervals_Ico hb, Nat.cast_add, Nat.cast_one,
    ← integral_interval_sub_left (a := a) (c := ⌊a⌋₊ + 1),
    ← integral_add_adjacent_intervals (b := ⌊b⌋₊) (c := b),
    integralmulsum c hf_diff hf_int _ _ _ aux3 aux1 le_rfl le_rfl aux4,
    integralmulsum c hf_diff hf_int _ _ _ aux5 le_rfl aux2 aux6 le_rfl]
  · ring
  -- now deal with the integrability side goals
  -- (Note we have 5 goals, but the 1st and 3rd are identical. TODO: find a non-hacky way of dealing
  -- with both at once.)
  · rw [intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le aux6]
    exact (integrablemulsum c ha hb hf_int).mono_set (Set.Icc_subset_Icc_right aux5)
  · rw [intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le aux5]
    exact (integrablemulsum c ha hb hf_int).mono_set (Set.Icc_subset_Icc_left aux6)
  · rw [intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le aux6]
    exact (integrablemulsum c ha hb hf_int).mono_set (Set.Icc_subset_Icc_right aux5)
  · rw [intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le aux3]
    exact (integrablemulsum c ha hb hf_int).mono_set (Set.Icc_subset_Icc_right aux4)
  · exact fun k hk ↦ (intervalIntegrable_iff_integrableOn_Icc_of_le (mod_cast k.le_succ)).mpr
      <| (integrablemulsum c ha hb hf_int).mono_set
        <| (Set.Icc_subset_Icc_iff (mod_cast k.le_succ)).mpr <| mod_cast (ineqofmemIco hk)
```
Most of the speedup comes from 2 things: firstly, `all_goals`, `any_goal` etc can take a while to fail on goals that don't fit, particularly if the goal (and tactic block) are complicated; secondly, `linarith` isn't all that good at recognising _fast_ if the goal is already in the context, which is actually true for every single one of the `linarith` calls in this proof as written.

When I started this proof, I found out there was many technical side conditions that needed to be checked and it was getting a bit cumbersome, thus I decided to see if it was possible to just postponed them all and try to close them automatically at the end with some tactic. I guess I went a bit overboard and ended up solving trivial facts using `linearity`. I did notice in the end that the proof was getting a bit slow. 

Anyway, thanks for the improvements!

pullRequest.title: feat(NumberTheory): Abel summation

Thanks!

Some comments on your proof.
- It's not much fun for authors, reviewers, or future editors to work on proofs of > 100 lines, because the tiniest edit causes the whole proof to recompile. Is there a way to extract some steps as separate lemmas (maybe flagged `private`)?
- You convert between ordered and un-ordered intervals **25 times** in this proof: 19 uses of `uIcc_of_le` and 6 more for the `Ioc` version. Are you sure there isn't a way of avoiding some of these conversions? As far as I can tell, for every `uIoc x y` or `uIcc x y` which appears in your argument, we always know straight away that `x ≤ y`; so why work with unordered intervals at all?
- `linarith` is an amazing tactic, but it can't see through the definition of intervals (ordered or unordered). Perhaps you could formulate `h_integ` and `h_locint` slightly differently, replacing the interval inclusions with explicitly-written inequalities, so that the proofs of the hypotheses could literally be `by linarith`?
Thanks for the comments. I'm going to be quite busy in the next few days but I'll find some time to improve the proof soon.

@loefflerd, I have modified the proof. Hopefully, it is better now. 

> * It's not much fun for authors, reviewers, or future editors to work on proofs of > 100 lines, because the tiniest edit causes the whole proof to recompile. Is there a way to extract some steps as separate lemmas (maybe flagged `private`)?

I have extracted several private lemmas from the main proof. I hope it makes things easier to work with. The proof is still quite technical, I am afraid,

> * You convert between ordered and un-ordered intervals **25 times** in this proof: 19 uses of `uIcc_of_le` and 6 more for the `Ioc` version. Are you sure there isn't a way of avoiding some of these conversions? As far as I can tell, for every `uIoc x y` or `uIcc x y` which appears in your argument, we always know straight away that `x ≤ y`; so why work with unordered intervals at all?

I tried to reduce the used of unordered intervals as much as possible. Still, at some point, there is the need to work with those because of the way [intervalIntegral](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Integral/IntervalIntegral.html#intervalIntegral) is defined. 

> * `linarith` is an amazing tactic, but it can't see through the definition of intervals (ordered or unordered). Perhaps you could formulate `h_integ` and `h_locint` slightly differently, replacing the interval inclusions with explicitly-written inequalities, so that the proofs of the hypotheses could literally be `by linarith`?

I replaced interval membership hypotheses  with explicit inequalities so that more things can be proved directly using `linarith`. I also tried to reduce the number of inequalities needed.
